subject: history
title: Last Phase of British Rule (1940-1947) - Key Events
description: Pakistan demand, Quit India, Cripps Mission, Cabinet Mission, Independence & Partition

details.where:
**Location**: Iqbal Park, Lahore (Minto Park)
**Session**: 27th Annual Session of All India Muslim League
**Date**: March 22-24, 1940
details.resolution:
**Moved by**: Fazlul Haq (Bengal Premier)
**Seconded by**: Choudhry Khaliquzzaman
**Demand**: Separate independent states for Muslims in:
‚Ä¢ Northwestern zones (Punjab, Sindh, NWFP, Baluchistan)
‚Ä¢ Eastern zones (Bengal, Assam)
**Note**: Resolution did NOT use word 'Pakistan' explicitly
But the demand clearly implied creation of Pakistan
details.twoNationTheory:
**Jinnah's Two-Nation Theory**:
‚Ä¢ Hindus and Muslims are two separate nations
‚Ä¢ They have different religions, cultures, languages, traditions
‚Ä¢ They cannot live together in one nation
‚Ä¢ Muslims need separate homeland for their protection
**Impact**: This theory became basis for Pakistan demand
details.significance:
**Historical Importance**:
‚Ä¢ First official demand for separate Muslim state
‚Ä¢ Rejected idea of united India
‚Ä¢ Marked beginning of partition movement
‚Ä¢ Changed course of Indian freedom struggle
‚Ä¢ Made partition almost inevitable

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ WWII started (Sep 1939) without consulting Indians
‚Ä¢ Congress ministries resigned in protest (Oct 1939)
‚Ä¢ British needed Indian support for war effort
‚Ä¢ Japan advancing in Asia; British position weakening
‚Ä¢ Viceroy Linlithgow made offer to gain Indian cooperation
details.offer:
**Viceroy Linlithgow's Proposals (Aug 8, 1940)**:
**1. Dominion Status**:
‚Ä¢ Promised Dominion Status after war ends
‚Ä¢ But no immediate transfer of power
**2. Expanded Executive Council**:
‚Ä¢ More Indians in Viceroy's Executive Council
‚Ä¢ But Viceroy retains final authority
**3. War Advisory Council**:
‚Ä¢ Advisory body for war-related matters
‚Ä¢ No real decision-making power
**4. Minority Veto**:
‚Ä¢ No new constitution without consent of minorities
‚Ä¢ Effectively gave veto power to Muslims
**5. Constituent Assembly**:
‚Ä¢ After war, Indians can frame constitution
‚Ä¢ But British would still control process
details.congress:
**Congress Reaction**:
‚Ä¢ **Rejected** the offer completely
‚Ä¢ **Reasons**:
  - Too vague; no immediate transfer of power
  - 'Post-dated cheque' (promise for future)
  - No real power sharing during war
  - Minority veto would block progress
‚Ä¢ **Gandhi's view**: Offer was 'insulting'
‚Ä¢ **Result**: Congress decided to launch Individual Satyagraha
details.league:
**Muslim League Reaction**:
‚Ä¢ **Also Rejected** the offer
‚Ä¢ **Reasons**:
  - Did not explicitly mention Pakistan
  - Wanted clear commitment to separate Muslim state
  - Not satisfied with just minority veto
‚Ä¢ **Jinnah's demand**: Explicit recognition of Pakistan demand
details.impact:
**Immediate Impact**:
‚Ä¢ Both Congress and League rejected offer
‚Ä¢ **Individual Satyagraha launched** (Oct 1940)
  - Limited civil disobedience
  - Selected individuals courted arrest
  - Vinoba Bhave first satyagrahi
  - Jawaharlal Nehru second
‚Ä¢ British position weakened further
‚Ä¢ Showed British offers were inadequate

details.offer:
**Cripps Proposals (March 22, 1942)**:
**1. Dominion Status**:
‚Ä¢ After war ends, India gets Dominion Status
‚Ä¢ Full independence within British Commonwealth
**2. Provinces Can Opt Out**:
‚Ä¢ Any province can refuse to join Indian Union
‚Ä¢ Can form separate dominion
‚Ä¢ **Implied**: Pakistan possible through this provision
**3. Constitution-Making Body**:
‚Ä¢ Indians can frame their own constitution
‚Ä¢ After war ends
**4. Defence During War**:
‚Ä¢ Defence remains with British during war
‚Ä¢ No immediate transfer of defence control
**5. Interim Government**:
‚Ä¢ Indians in Executive Council
‚Ä¢ But Viceroy retains final authority
details.congress:
**Congress Reaction**:
‚Ä¢ **Rejected** the proposals
‚Ä¢ **Gandhi's famous quote**: 'Post-dated cheque on a failing bank'
‚Ä¢ **Reasons for rejection**:
  - No immediate transfer of power
  - Defence remains with British
  - Provinces can opt out (partition implied)
  - No real power during war
  - Constitution-making delayed till after war
‚Ä¢ **Nehru's view**: Proposals were 'inadequate'
‚Ä¢ **Maulana Azad**: Negotiated but found proposals unacceptable
details.league:
**Muslim League Reaction**:
‚Ä¢ **Also Rejected** the proposals
‚Ä¢ **Reasons**:
  - No explicit mention of Pakistan
  - Provinces opt-out provision was indirect
  - Wanted clear commitment to separate state
  - Jinnah wanted explicit Pakistan recognition
‚Ä¢ **Jinnah's demand**: Direct creation of Pakistan, not through opt-out
details.significance:
**Why Mission Failed**:
‚Ä¢ **'Too late, too little'**:
  - British waited too long
  - Indians had lost trust
  - Proposals were too little, too vague
‚Ä¢ **Defence issue**: Major sticking point
‚Ä¢ **Partition implied**: Opt-out provision suggested partition
‚Ä¢ **No immediate power**: Indians wanted power now, not after war
details.impact:
**Consequences**:
‚Ä¢ Mission failed completely
‚Ä¢ British position weakened further
‚Ä¢ **Quit India Movement** launched (Aug 1942)
‚Ä¢ Showed British offers were always inadequate
‚Ä¢ Made partition more likely (opt-out provision)

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ Cripps Mission failed (March 1942)
‚Ä¢ Japan advancing; British position weak
‚Ä¢ Congress frustrated with British offers
‚Ä¢ Gandhi decided: 'Time for final struggle'
‚Ä¢ All-India Congress Committee (AICC) met in Bombay
details.resolution:
**Bombay Session (August 8, 1942)**:
‚Ä¢ **Venue**: Gowalia Tank Maidan, Bombay (now August Kranti Maidan)
‚Ä¢ **Resolution**: 'Quit India' resolution passed
‚Ä¢ **Demand**: Immediate British withdrawal from India
‚Ä¢ **Method**: Mass civil disobedience
‚Ä¢ **Gandhi's speech**: 'Do or Die' - famous call
‚Ä¢ **Vote**: Overwhelmingly passed
details.slogan:
**Famous Slogans**:
‚Ä¢ **'Do or Die'** (Gandhi's call)
‚Ä¢ **'Quit India'** (main demand)
‚Ä¢ **'Bharat Chodo'** (Hindi version)
‚Ä¢ **'Karenge ya Marenge'** (We will do or die)
details.arrests:
**Mass Arrests (August 9, 1942)**:
‚Ä¢ **Early morning**: British arrested entire Congress leadership
‚Ä¢ **Arrested**:
  - Mahatma Gandhi, Jawaharlal Nehru, Sardar Patel, Maulana Azad, All top Congress leaders
‚Ä¢ **Strategy**: Decapitate movement by removing leaders
‚Ä¢ **Result**: Movement became leaderless
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **Largest mass movement** in Indian freedom struggle
‚Ä¢ **Showed British can't rule** without Indian consent
‚Ä¢ **Proved mass support** for independence
‚Ä¢ **Strengthened demand** for immediate freedom
‚Ä¢ **Exposed British brutality** to world
‚Ä¢ **Made independence inevitable**
‚Ä¢ **Last major movement** before independence
details.exam:
**MOST ASKED IN EXAMS**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: August 8, 1942 (resolution passed)
‚Ä¢ **Arrests**: August 9, 1942 (early morning)
‚Ä¢ **Venue**: Gowalia Tank Maidan, Bombay
‚Ä¢ **Slogan**: 'Do or Die' (Gandhi)
‚Ä¢ **Resolution**: 'Quit India'
‚Ä¢ **Nature**: Leaderless mass movement
‚Ä¢ **Arrested**: Gandhi, Nehru, Patel, Azad (all leaders)
‚Ä¢ **Repression**: 1,00,000+ arrested, 1,000+ killed
‚Ä¢ **Also called**: August Kranti / August Revolution

details.context:
**Background (1943)**:
‚Ä¢ WWII ongoing; British war policies affected food supply
‚Ä¢ Japanese occupied Burma (main rice supplier)
‚Ä¢ British diverted food to war effort
‚Ä¢ Hoarding by traders and landlords
‚Ä¢ Natural factors: floods, cyclones in Bengal
details.causes:
**Causes of Famine**:
‚Ä¢ **British war policies**:
  - Food diverted to military
  - Export restrictions not imposed
  - Price controls ineffective
‚Ä¢ **Hoarding**:
  - Traders hoarded grain
  - Landlords profiteered
  - Black market flourished
‚Ä¢ **Churchill's refusal**:
  - Refused grain ships from Australia/Canada
  - Prioritized war over Indian lives
  - Racist attitude towards Indians
details.impact:
**Impact**:
‚Ä¢ **Exposed British callousness**:
  - Showed British didn't care about Indian lives
  - Strengthened anti-British sentiment
‚Ä¢ **Political impact**:
  - Increased support for independence
  - Made British rule morally indefensible
‚Ä¢ **Social impact**:
  - Mass migration
  - Social disruption
  - Long-term trauma

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ Subhash Chandra Bose formed INA (Indian National Army)
‚Ä¢ INA fought alongside Japan against British
‚Ä¢ After Japan's defeat, INA soldiers captured
‚Ä¢ British decided to try them for treason
‚Ä¢ Trials held at Red Fort, Delhi
details.reaction:
**Massive Public Support**:
‚Ä¢ **Nationwide protests**:
  - Students, workers, peasants demonstrated
  - 'Release INA heroes' slogans
  - Processions and meetings
‚Ä¢ **Legal defence**:
  - Bhulabhai Desai, Nehru, Asaf Ali defended
  - Famous lawyers volunteered
‚Ä¢ **Public opinion**:
  - INA seen as freedom fighters
  - Not traitors but patriots
  - Massive sympathy
details.communal:
**Hindu-Muslim-Sikh Unity**:
‚Ä¢ Three accused from three communities
‚Ä¢ United support across religious lines
‚Ä¢ Showed nationalism transcended communalism
‚Ä¢ Last major show of unity before partition
details.outcome:
**Trial Outcome**:
‚Ä¢ **British forced to release**:
  - Couldn't punish due to public pressure
  - Feared massive uprising
  - Reduced sentences
  - Eventually released
‚Ä¢ **Victory for Indians**:
  - Public opinion won
  - British authority challenged
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **Showed British military loyalty shaken**:
  - Indian soldiers supported INA
  - British couldn't rely on Indian army
‚Ä¢ **Made British rule untenable**:
  - If army supports independence, British can't rule
  - Realized they must leave
‚Ä¢ **Paved way for independence**:
  - British confidence shattered
  - Independence became inevitable

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ INA Trials created sympathy for freedom fighters
‚Ä¢ Indian sailors in Royal Indian Navy discontented
‚Ä¢ Poor food, racial discrimination
‚Ä¢ Low pay, bad conditions
‚Ä¢ Inspired by INA heroes
details.event:
**The Mutiny (Feb 18, 1946)**:
‚Ä¢ **Started**: HMIS Talwar (Bombay)
‚Ä¢ **Spread to**:
  - Bombay (main center), Karachi, Calcutta, Other ports
‚Ä¢ **Actions**:
  - Hoisted Congress, League, Red flags
  - Took control of ships
  - Refused British orders
  - Demanded better conditions + independence
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **Showed armed forces' loyalty gone**:
  - Navy mutinied
  - Army sympathy for INA
  - British couldn't rely on Indian forces
‚Ä¢ **British realized they can't hold India by force**:
  - If armed forces rebel, British can't rule
  - Must negotiate transfer of power
  - Independence became urgent
‚Ä¢ **Last nail in British coffin**:
  - After INA Trials + Naval Mutiny
  - British position completely untenable

details.members:
**Cabinet Mission Members**:
‚Ä¢ **Lord Pethick-Lawrence** (Secretary of State for India)
‚Ä¢ **Sir Stafford Cripps** (President of Board of Trade)
‚Ä¢ **A.V. Alexander** (First Lord of Admiralty)
‚Ä¢ All senior British ministers
‚Ä¢ Arrived in India: March 24, 1946
details.plan:
**Cabinet Mission Plan (May 16, 1946)**:
**1. United India with Weak Center**:
‚Ä¢ India to remain united
‚Ä¢ Center controls: Defence, Foreign Affairs, Communications
‚Ä¢ All other subjects with provinces
**2. Provinces Grouped**:
‚Ä¢ **Group A**: Hindu-majority provinces (Madras, Bombay, UP, Bihar, CP, Orissa)
‚Ä¢ **Group B**: Muslim-majority NW (Punjab, NWFP, Sindh, Baluchistan)
‚Ä¢ **Group C**: Muslim-majority East (Bengal, Assam)
**3. Constituent Assembly**:
‚Ä¢ Indians frame constitution
‚Ä¢ Representatives from all groups
**4. No Pakistan**:
‚Ä¢ Explicitly rejected Pakistan demand
‚Ä¢ But grouping gave Muslims effective control
details.initial:
**Initial Acceptance**:
‚Ä¢ **Congress**: Accepted plan initially
  - Saw it as step towards independence
  - United India maintained
‚Ä¢ **Muslim League**: Also accepted initially
  - Grouping gave them power
  - Saw it as Pakistan in all but name
‚Ä¢ **Both signed**: Agreement seemed possible
details.breakdown:
**Why It Broke Down**:
‚Ä¢ **Conflicting interpretations**:
  - **Congress**: Grouping optional, provinces can opt out
  - **League**: Grouping compulsory, provinces must stay
‚Ä¢ **Nehru's statement** (July 10, 1946):
  - Said Congress not bound by grouping
  - League saw this as betrayal
‚Ä¢ **Jinnah's reaction**:
  - Withdrew acceptance
  - Called for 'Direct Action'
‚Ä¢ **Result**: Plan collapsed
details.result:
**Final Outcome**:
‚Ä¢ Mission failed
‚Ä¢ **Direct Action Day** called (Aug 16, 1946)
‚Ä¢ Communal violence erupted
‚Ä¢ Partition became inevitable
‚Ä¢ Last chance for united India lost

events.title: Direct Action Day - Great Calcutta Killings

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ Cabinet Mission Plan broke down
‚Ä¢ Jinnah felt betrayed by Congress
‚Ä¢ League decided to use force
‚Ä¢ Called for 'Direct Action' to achieve Pakistan
‚Ä¢ August 16 declared as Direct Action Day
details.call:
**Jinnah's Call**:
‚Ä¢ **'Direct Action'** for Pakistan
‚Ä¢ Muslims should take to streets
‚Ä¢ Show strength and determination
‚Ä¢ Force British to grant Pakistan
‚Ä¢ No more negotiations
‚Ä¢ **Slogan**: 'Lekar rahenge Pakistan' (We will take Pakistan)
details.calcutta:
**Great Calcutta Killings (Aug 16, 1946)**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: August 16, 1946
‚Ä¢ **Location**: Calcutta (now Kolkata)
‚Ä¢ **Nature**: Worst communal riots in Indian history
‚Ä¢ **Deaths**: 4,000+ killed in just 3 days
‚Ä¢ **Violence**:
  - Mass killings, arson, looting
‚Ä¢ **Both sides**: Hindus and Muslims killed each other
‚Ä¢ **British**: Did little to stop violence

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ Cabinet Mission Plan suggested interim government
‚Ä¢ British wanted to transfer power gradually
‚Ä¢ Indians to gain experience in governance
‚Ä¢ Congress agreed to form government
‚Ä¢ League initially refused
details.formation:
**Formation (September 2, 1946)**:
‚Ä¢ **Viceroy**: Lord Wavell
‚Ä¢ **Vice President** (PM equivalent): Jawaharlal Nehru
‚Ä¢ **Congress-dominated**:
  - Most ministers from Congress
  - Key portfolios with Congress
  - Sardar Patel (Home)
  - Rajendra Prasad (Food)
  - Others
‚Ä¢ **Function**: Run administration till independence
details.league:
**Muslim League Joins (October 1946)**:
‚Ä¢ League initially boycotted
‚Ä¢ Later joined (Oct 26, 1946)
‚Ä¢ **But remained uncooperative**:
  - Obstructed government work
  - Refused to attend meetings
  - Created conflicts
  - Demanded Pakistan
details.conflict:
**Constant Friction**:
‚Ä¢ **League obstruction**:
  - Blocked decisions
  - Created deadlocks
  - No cooperation
‚Ä¢ **Congress frustration**:
  - Couldn't function properly
  - League sabotaged work
  - Constant conflicts
‚Ä¢ **No unity**:
  - Two parallel governments
  - No joint decisions
  - Complete breakdown

events.title: Attlee's Statement - British to Leave by June 1948

details.announcement:
**Attlee's Statement (February 20, 1947)**:
‚Ä¢ **PM Clement Attlee** (British Prime Minister)
‚Ä¢ **Announcement**: British will leave India by **June 1948**
‚Ä¢ **Fixed deadline**: 16 months from announcement
‚Ä¢ **Unconditional**: No conditions attached
‚Ä¢ **Transfer power**: To Indians by fixed date
‚Ä¢ **Historic**: First time British set deadline to leave
details.deadline:
**Impact of Fixed Deadline**:
‚Ä¢ **Increased urgency**:
  - Indians had to agree quickly
  - No time for prolonged negotiations
  - Forced compromise
‚Ä¢ **Forced Indians to agree**:
  - Congress and League had to accept partition
  - No alternative left
  - Violence made delay dangerous
‚Ä¢ **Accelerated process**:
  - Independence process speeded up
  - Mountbatten appointed to execute
details.mountbatten:
**Lord Mountbatten Appointed**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: March 1947
‚Ä¢ **Position**: Last Viceroy of India
‚Ä¢ **Task**: Transfer power by June 1948
‚Ä¢ **Authority**: Full powers to decide
‚Ä¢ **Background**: Royal family member, war hero
‚Ä¢ **Decision**: Advanced independence to August 1947

details.plan:
**Mountbatten Plan (June 3, 1947)**:
**1. India to be Partitioned**:
‚Ä¢ Two separate countries
‚Ä¢ India (Hindu-majority)
‚Ä¢ Pakistan (Muslim-majority)
**2. Punjab & Bengal Divided**:
‚Ä¢ Both provinces split
‚Ä¢ Hindu areas to India
‚Ä¢ Muslim areas to Pakistan
**3. Boundary Commission**:
‚Ä¢ **Sir Cyril Radcliffe** (British lawyer)
‚Ä¢ Draw boundary lines
‚Ä¢ Divide Punjab and Bengal
**4. Princely States**:
‚Ä¢ Free to join either India or Pakistan
‚Ä¢ Or remain independent
‚Ä¢ **Suzerainty** of British Crown ends
**5. Two Dominions**:
‚Ä¢ India and Pakistan
‚Ä¢ Both get Dominion Status
‚Ä¢ Within British Commonwealth
details.acceptance:
**Acceptance by All Parties**:
‚Ä¢ **Congress**: Accepted (reluctantly)
  - No choice; violence escalating
  - Better than civil war
  - Accepted partition as price for independence
‚Ä¢ **Muslim League**: Accepted (happily)
  - Got Pakistan
  - Achieved goal
  - Jinnah satisfied
‚Ä¢ **Sikhs**: Accepted (unhappily)
  - Punjab divided
  - Many Sikhs on wrong side
  - But no alternative
‚Ä¢ **All agreed**: Partition was only solution
details.date:
**Independence Date Advanced**:
‚Ä¢ **Original deadline**: June 1948
‚Ä¢ **New date**: **August 15, 1947**
‚Ä¢ **Advanced by**: 10 months
‚Ä¢ **Reason**:
  - Violence escalating
  - Delay dangerous
  - Better to leave quickly
‚Ä¢ **Mountbatten's decision**:
  - Chose Aug 15 (Japan surrender anniversary)
  - Symbolic date
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **Formal acceptance of partition**:
  - All parties agreed
  - Partition became official
  - No going back
‚Ä¢ **End of British rule**:
  - British to leave
  - 200 years of rule ending
  - Independence coming
‚Ä¢ **Beginning of new era**:
  - Two new nations
  - Independence and partition together

details.british:
**British Parliament Action**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: July 18, 1947
‚Ä¢ **Act**: Indian Independence Act 1947
‚Ä¢ **Passed by**: British Parliament
‚Ä¢ **Royal Assent**: July 18, 1947
‚Ä¢ **Creates**: Two new dominions
‚Ä¢ **Ends**: British sovereignty over India
details.provisions:
**Main Provisions of the Act**:
**1. Two Dominions**:
‚Ä¢ India (Hindu-majority areas)
‚Ä¢ Pakistan (Muslim-majority areas)
‚Ä¢ Both get Dominion Status
**2. Constituent Assemblies**:
‚Ä¢ Each dominion gets Constituent Assembly
‚Ä¢ **Sovereign**: Can frame own constitution
‚Ä¢ No British interference
**3. British Crown's Sovereignty Ends**:
‚Ä¢ British King no longer Emperor of India
‚Ä¢ Sovereignty transferred to Indians
‚Ä¢ Complete independence
**4. Partition Details**:
‚Ä¢ Punjab and Bengal divided
‚Ä¢ Boundary as per Radcliffe Award
‚Ä¢ Princely states free to join either
details.date:
**Effective Date**:
‚Ä¢ **Act comes into effect**: August 15, 1947
‚Ä¢ **From this date**:
  - British rule ends
  - Two dominions created
  - Independence begins
  - Partition implemented
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **Legal end of British rule**:
  - Formally ends British sovereignty
  - India becomes independent
  - 200 years of colonial rule over
‚Ä¢ **Creates two nations**:
  - India and Pakistan
  - Both independent
  - Both sovereign
‚Ä¢ **New beginning**:
  - Indians rule themselves
  - Can frame own constitution
  - Complete freedom

details.context:
**Background**:
‚Ä¢ Indian Independence Act passed (July 18)
‚Ä¢ Radcliffe Award announced (Aug 17)
‚Ä¢ Preparations for transfer of power
‚Ä¢ Mixed emotions: joy and sorrow
‚Ä¢ Historic moment approaching
details.pakistan:
**Pakistan Created (August 14, 1947)**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: August 14, 1947
‚Ä¢ **First**: Pakistan created (one day before India)
‚Ä¢ **Governor-General**: Muhammad Ali Jinnah
‚Ä¢ **Prime Minister**: Liaquat Ali Khan
‚Ä¢ **Capital**: Karachi
‚Ä¢ **Territory**: West Pakistan + East Pakistan (Bangladesh)
‚Ä¢ **Celebration**: Muslims celebrated across subcontinent
details.india:
**India Independent (August 15, 1947)**:
‚Ä¢ **Date**: August 15, 1947
‚Ä¢ **Historic Day**: Independence achieved
‚Ä¢ **Governor-General**: Lord Mountbatten (till June 1948)
‚Ä¢ **Prime Minister**: Jawaharlal Nehru
‚Ä¢ **Capital**: New Delhi
‚Ä¢ **Nehru's Speech**: 'Tryst with Destiny' at midnight
‚Ä¢ **Celebration**: Tricolor hoisted; Joy across India
details.punjab:
**Punjab & Bengal Divided**:
‚Ä¢ **Radcliffe Line**:
  - Drawn by Sir Cyril Radcliffe
  - Divided Punjab and Bengal
  - Announced August 17, 1947
‚Ä¢ **Punjab**:
  - West Punjab ‚Üí Pakistan
  - East Punjab ‚Üí India
  - Massive migration
‚Ä¢ **Bengal**:
  - East Bengal ‚Üí Pakistan (later Bangladesh)
  - West Bengal ‚Üí India
  - Division traumatic
details.significance:
**Historical Significance**:
‚Ä¢ **End of British Rule**:
  - 200 years of colonial rule over
  - Indians free
  - Sovereignty regained
‚Ä¢ **Beginning of New Era**:
  - Two independent nations
  - Can frame own destiny
  - New challenges ahead
‚Ä¢ **Price Paid**:
  - Partition violence
  - Human tragedy
  - But freedom achieved

examTips.critical_dates: Mar 23, 1940 (Pakistan demand); Aug 8-9, 1942 (Quit India); Jun 3, 1947 (Mountbatten Plan); Aug 15, 1947 (Independence)

examTips.violence: Direct Action (Aug 16, 1946) made partition inevitable; INA & Naval Mutiny showed British can't hold India
